feed.title: Open Source and Reproducible MIR Research
feed.subtitle: The goal of this tutorial is to provide hands-on, practical training for MIR researchers to learn modern tools for improving the quality of their research software.

entry.title: Part 1: Installing Tools
entry.content:
Welcome! This part of the tutorial will cover installing the tools that you‚Äôll need to have on your laptop: the Python programming language, the Conda package manager, and the git version control system.

Install Python

Visit the main Python page, and download Python 3.6 or higher.

Mac users, you very probably have Python 2.7 on your computer ‚Äì please do go and get Python 3.6.

Linux users, you have some version of Python on your machine ‚Äì please make sure that you have Python 3.6, and go and get it if not.

Windows users, we highly recommend that you install the [Windows System for Linux][wsl-install] and Ubuntu. You can then do the rest of this tutorial as a Linux user! While you‚Äôre welcome to use Powershell, we can‚Äôt guarantee that we‚Äôll be able to help you!

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

(You‚Äôll see these checkpoints throughout the tutorial. If you‚Äôre doing the tutorial with us in person, we‚Äôll stop at these points to make sure that everyone is in the same place. If your checkpoint is working, you can put a blue sticky note on your laptop. If something‚Äôs not working, that‚Äôs totally OK! Put a red sticky note on your machine, and we‚Äôll come help.)

Install Conda

Conda is a package manager for Python code and lower-level code that supports Python. Anaconda is a version of Conda that comes with lots and lots of pre-installed packages for scientific computing. We‚Äôre going to use Anaconda so we don‚Äôt have to go digging for obscure Fortran and C libraries.

Visit the Anaconda website, and follow the steps for your platform.

Windows users, please use your Linux install, and install the Linux version!

Gotchas:

  • If you‚Äôre using zsh or another non-bash shell, you‚Äôll need to add things to your PATH yourself. We recommend moving the lines that the installer added from your .bash_profile file to your .zshrc file
  • If you‚Äôre using a virtualenv, you‚Äôll need to turn it off before installing Anaconda! Conda in general does not play well with virtualenvs.

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Install git

git is a version control system ‚Äì it keeps track of changes that you make to your code. This makes it hard for you to lose changes that you have made, and makes it easy for you to return to a working version of your code. git in particular also makes it easy to collaborate with other folks.

Visit the git website, and follow the steps for your platform.

Linux users, you may already have git installed - please make sure that you‚Äôre on version 2.15 or or higher.

Windows users, please use your Linux install, and install the Linux version! (We‚Äôll stop reminding you about this soon, we promise.)

We recommend against using a graphical interface for git ‚Äì mostly because we won‚Äôt be able to help you with it in this tutorial!

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Success!

We‚Äôve installed everything we‚Äôll need on our machines. In Part 2, we‚Äôll set up the various web apps and accounts that we‚Äôll need.

entry.title: Part 2: Setting Up Services
entry.content:
Welcome to Part 2! In this section we‚Äôll set up accounts for the web services that we need ‚Äì GitHub, Travis CI, and ReadTheDocs.

Set Up GitHub

GitHub hosts your code, makes it easy for other folks to collaborate with you, and makes it easier for other web services to hook into your code

Vist GitHub, and create an account. Once you‚Äôve got an account, you need to create some SSH keys.

SSH keys are big numbers that GitHub uses for authorization. Setting them up can be a bit fincky, but we‚Äôll get through it!

First, create a new SSH key by following these steps ‚Äì make sure to pick the correct platform.

Now, we‚Äôll add the key to our GitHub account. The steps to do so are here ‚Äì again, make sure you pick the correct platform!

Finally, let‚Äôs verify that your key works! The steps are here.

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Set Up Travis CI

Travis CI is a tool for ‚ÄúContinuous Integration‚Äù, which is just a fancy word for running the code that tests your software whenever you change your software. We won‚Äôt get to using Travis for a little bit, but let‚Äôs get the setup out of the way now.

Visit Travis, and make an account by pressing the Sign In With GitHub button.

You‚Äôll be asked to authorize Travis to use your Github account. Do so, and you‚Äôll get redirected to your profile screen. On your profile screen, press the ‚ÄúActivate‚Äù button to finish connecting Travis to you GitHub code.

You‚Äôll be taken to a GitHub page - just press ‚ÄúApprove & Install‚Äù!

Checkpoint

No command line here - you should be able to visit Travis, and see your name in the upper-right to indicate that you‚Äôre logged in.

Set Up ReadTheDocs

ReadTheDocs hosts your documentation, so that people know how to use your software! We‚Äôll get to ReadTheDocs nearer to the end of the tutorial, but let‚Äôs get things set up now.

Visit ReadTheDocs, and press Sign up, and the select Sign Up With GitHub. Like with Travis, you‚Äôll be asked to authorize ReadTheDocs to use your GitHub account ‚Äì do the same as you did before. ReadTheDocs will also ask you to confirm your email, so open up your email client and do so.

Checkpoint

No command line here either - you should be able to visit ReadTheDocs and see your GitHub username in the upper-right to indicate that you‚Äôre logged in.

Success!

We‚Äôve set up the various web services we‚Äôll need! Next is Part 3, where we‚Äôll get to the code!

A Note About The Internet

All of the services we‚Äôve go over are on the internet. There are local tools that can do the same sorts of things that out of the scope of this tutorial. If you need to keep you code secret, they might be right for you. In general, we recommend using web services like the above because they‚Äôre much less hassle to set up.

entry.title: Part 3: Getting the Code
entry.content:
Hello & welcome to Part 3! This is where we‚Äôll start to use the various things you‚Äôve installed to work with the code.

Get the Code

We‚Äôre going to go over some real-world basics of how git works and how conda works. We‚Äôll do this by getting you a copy of the code we‚Äôre going to work with on to your local machine, then installing the packages we need with conda.

Visit https://github.com/bmcfee/shablona, and press the Fork button. You‚Äôll be asked where to fork the code to ‚Äì select your own GitHub username. A ‚Äúfork‚Äù is your own copy of our code. You can change it without altering our code.

Now, visit https://github.com/<your-username>/shablona, and press the Clone button. Make sure to select Clone with SSH, and then copy the string that looks like git@github:<your-username>/shablona.git

Then, in your terminal, go to wherever you keep your code, and do git clone <that string>. This will do a lot of stuff! Once it is done, you should see a directory called shablona.

cd into that directory, then do ls. You should see the same files that you see on GitHub!

Checkpoint

From the shablona directory, run:

You should see:

Install Things with Conda

Conda, like we said earlier, is both a package manager and an environment manager. A package manager just installs things for you. An environment manager is a bit more complex ‚Äì it keeps track of different indepenent environments, each of which can have different things installed. So, for example, you can have one environment for this project and install the things that you need ‚Ä¶ and then have a different environment for a different project, with different packages installed!

This may sound like overkill, but it is very helpful in the long run. You‚Äôll often find that different projects have clashing requirements, and maintaining one environment per project will prevent this from getting out of hand.

So, let‚Äôs make one and install the code that we need! To create an environment for this tutorial, do conda create --name ismir-2018. You‚Äôll see that environment has been created at /Users/<your-user>/miniconda3/envs/ismir-2018-tutorial! Hooray! To turn it on do conda activate ismir-2018-tutorial.

This means that any Python code you install with conda or pip will only be installed in this environment. If you want to get out of this environment, just run source deactivate ‚Äì but don‚Äôt run it now!

For now, we‚Äôre going to install all the stuff we need. Run conda install --file requirements.txt. Lots of things should happen!

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see something like the below ‚Äì make sure that librosa is in list!

Run the Tests

So we‚Äôve installed all the packages we‚Äôll need. Let‚Äôs run the tests. Tests make sure that your code is doing what your think it is doing ‚Äì making sure that 2 + 2 in fact comes out to 4.

You can find the test code in the tests/ folder, and we‚Äôll talk more about testing later in the tutorial. For now, just run the tests with pytest.

üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí• OH NO EVERYTHING FAILED! üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•üî•üí•

Phew, ok, this is not actually a big deal at all. Failing tests are usually a good sign, becaue they mean that your tests found a bug or a problem. Let‚Äôs look at the error message that pytest is showing, and see if we can fix it.

Ah, this does not look so bad. We‚Äôre missing a package called pandas. We could just install it with conda, but we want to fix this problem for the long term. So, open up that requirements.txt file, and add the line pandas at the bottom, and the save it. Then re-run conda install --file requirements.txt, and then run the tests again.

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Save Our Work

We fixed a bug, hooray! But we‚Äôve only fixed our local version. Let‚Äôs commit this to our local git repository, and then update the version on GitHub.

First, make a new branch to work on. Working in a branch means that we can do whatever we want without breaking our main code. Do git branch update-conda-env.

Next, add and commit your files: git add requirements.txt, then git commit -m "Add pandas to requirements.txt"

Rad! We‚Äôve saved our work locally. To push your code to GitHub, do git push origin update-conda-env.

We want to get in the habit of keeping our online work up to date with our local work. So let‚Äôs go look at GitHub, and merge this branch there.

  • Visit GitHub, and find your fork of this repository: https://github.com//shablona/branches
  • You‚Äôll see a list of branches - select update-conda-env.
  • You‚Äôll see a small button that says New pull request. Press it!
  • This will take you to a nice web form. Put in the reasons for your changes, and press Create Pull Request.

Hooray, you‚Äôve made a Pull Request! Pull Requests (PRs) are the best way to contribute code to a project. You can review & comment on the proposed changes before merging them, or request that things be improved.

üôè Here‚Äôs an important aside: when discussing code in PRs, please be nice! It‚Äôs really easy for a neutral comment to be read as mean, and it‚Äôs really easy to alienate people by being mean You should do your best to very polite and kind when dealing with people on GitHub (and probably on computers in general).

With that said, let‚Äôs merge our PR! This will add the changes from your branch to the master branch.

  • Press Merge. GitHub will merge your commit into master.
  • Now your online repo is up to date, so let‚Äôs update your local.
  • In your command line, run git checkout master.
  • Next, do git pull origin master to update your local copy. You‚Äôll see that git adds your commit from GitHub to your local copy.
  • Finally, do git branch -d update-conda-env to delete your local branch ‚Äì you‚Äôve merged the commits to master, so you can delete it.

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see something like this:

We‚Äôve just gone over the basic git and GitHub workflow that you should, in general, stick with: make a branch, make some changes, run tests, commit, push, merge, clean up.

This means that you never have untested code in master, and it means that master is always functional. This is called ‚ÄúContinuous Integration‚Äù, or ‚ÄúContinuous Delivery‚Äù. There are whole books about why this is a good idea, but you can read a good summary of the GitHub version of it here.

It also means that the online, ‚Äúdeployed‚Äù version of master is your primary version, and you just have a local version that you‚Äôre working on.

Success!

We‚Äôve used git to check out code, modify it, and commit our modifications. We‚Äôve also used conda to install the code we need, in an environment that is specific to this project. In [Part 4][tutorial-part-4], we‚Äôll get into the details of our Python code and how it all fits together.

entry.title: Part 5: Tests
entry.content:
Hello & welcome to Part 5! This is the section about testing, why testing is important, how to do it, and how to set up your repository to run your tests automatically when you push new code.

Why Shall We Test Our Code?

Tests make your life easier and give you confidence in your code. Software is complicated, and tests allow you to be sure that you‚Äôve not broken your project when you change something.

Writing tests slows you down in the short term, but speeds things up in the long term. Further, as someone who is writing scientific code, tests make sure that your work can be easily reproduced.

Fix A Failing Test

Let‚Äôs start by working through fixing a failing test, and commiting the results to our repository.

Start by making a new branch, with git checkout -b fix-failing-test.

Then open up <some-filename>, uncomment the function called <test_some_function>, and then run pytest.

The test failed, oh no!

So, that test is testing a function that we‚Äôve stubbed out, but that returns obviously incorrect results.

You can find the function in <filename> - go ahead and fix the function so that the tests pass. Run pytest as much as you want to, to make sure.

Great! You should also write a new test to verify that this function works correctly for <some edge casee>.

Philosophically, each test should test one thing. This makes it easier to ensure that we can see what has broken when a test breaks.

Once pytest shows that both tests are passing, commit your changes, merge on github, and then pull the results back to your local.

Checkpoint

Run:

You should see:

Get Travis Working

We set up our Travis account in Part 2! Travis is a service that runs your tests when you push new branches to GitHub. This is useful because it means that you can‚Äôt forget to run your tests ‚Äì and it means that other people‚Äôs PRs will have tests run against them.

Travis is controlled by a file called .travis.yml. This file tells the Travis servers what to do with your code - in our case, just run the tests.

We‚Äôve written the file for you. Let‚Äôs take a quick look at it. The big install block handles the gruntwork of installing conda, updating it, and setting up our environment. The script block is what Travis runs. We currently just run pytest.

Let‚Äôs modify this to run flake8 as well. flake8 checks your code style, to make sure that you‚Äôre writing code that is easy to read.

All you need to do is add flake8 below the call to pytest, then commit and push your code.

Then, open up Travis, and you can see your tests run!

Gotchas:

  • Rarely, your tests will pass locally but fail on Travis. This is super frustrating, and is usually caused by there being a difference between your local environment and the Travis environment.

TODO ADD SOME WORDS HERE AND A BETTER TEST TODO

Success!

We‚Äôve added two tests, and gotten comfortable running pytest. Furthermore, we‚Äôve enabled Travis, so that our tests always run when we push code to GitHub. In Part 6, we‚Äôll set up our documentation so that it builds automatically, and write some new docs.

entry.title: Part 6: Documentation
entry.content:
Hello & welcome to Part 6! This section is about documentation, how to set up our documentation, and how to hows our documentation for free on the internet.

Build Some Docs

Documentation is super important! Good docs help people use and understand your software. This includes both readme files that help people get started, and detailed docs for each method.

We‚Äôre going to use a thing called Sphinx to generate our documentation from the comments we leave in our code. Sphinx is really complicated and powerful, but we‚Äôll be using it in a pretty simple way.

cd into the doc folder, and take a look around. You‚Äôll see a bunch of Sphnix boilerplate code. The exact code here is not something you should worry about! Instead, run make html ‚Äì this will generate all your documentation for you, in _build/html.

Checkpoint

  • Open _build/html/index.html in a web browser.

You should see:

  • A working webpage!

Get ReadTheDocs Working

We set up our ReadTheDocs account in Part 2 ‚Äì RTD is a service that builds and hosts your docs for you.

Checkpoint

‚Äì invoke Brian McFee ‚Äì

Write Some Docs

Rad, so we know how to make our docs, this is great. But where do all those words come from?

It turns out that Sphinx reads from comments that are formatted in a certain way. This is cool because it means we can write good comments in our code, and have those comments automatically turn into our docs!

Find in - you'll see that it does not have any documentation. Take a look at - you'll see that it has a detailed description of how it works, what parameters it takes, and what it returns.

Based on this example, add a docstring to . Once you're happy with your docs, commit, push, and merge them to github - and Read The Docs will build your new docs for you!

Checkpoint

  • Visit your site on ReadTheDocs

You should see:

  • A working webpage, with your new docstring!

README and LICENSE

We‚Äôve got formal documentation working, hooray! You should also look at two other files. README.md is your readme file ‚Äì it‚Äôs the first thing that people see when they visit your project on GitHub.

In general, your README should provided an overview of your project, how to install it, and maybe give one or two very simple examples. The librosa README is a good example.

Finally, there‚Äôs LICENSE.md. It turns out that if f you publish code to GitHub without an explicit license, it is not open source.

We highly recommend open source, and we highly recommend choosing an open-source license and applying it to your code. This is as simple as creating a file called LICENSE.md in your repository. You can take a look at https://choosealicense.com to help you pick one - we recommend the MIT license, ourselves.

Success!

We‚Äôve added some documentation, and set up ReadTheDocs so that our docs will always be available on the Internet! We also talked about READMEs and licensing. This is the last bit of the tutorial proper ‚Äì thanks for following along!
